snippet: The presence of a United States-flagged aircraft in Iran is highly unusual these days, especially when it’s owned by a small Utah bank.
abstract: American and Iranian officials decline to comment on arrival of a plane owned by the Bank of Utah in Iran; under United States law, any American aircraft would need prior approval from Treasury Dept to go to Iran; bank officials say they have no idea why plane was there, and are investigating further.

byline.original: By MICHAEL CORKERY, JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and THOMAS ERDBRINK
byline.contributor: Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg reported from New York, and Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran. Rick Gladstone contributed reporting from New York, and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The presence of a United States-flagged aircraft in Iran is highly unusual these days, especially when it’s owned by a small Utah bank.

headline.main: Iran Gets an Unlikely Visitor, an American Plane, but No One Seems to Know Why
headline.print_headline: Iran Gets an Unlikely Visitor, an American Plane, but No One Seems to Know Why
